pageData.text: In linear motion, unbalanced forces cause objects to change their state of motion; in rotational motion, unbalanced <button class='glossary-text'>torques</button> cause objects to change their state of rotational motion. If the system is in equilibrium, the net force will be equal to zero, and the net torque will be equal to zero. In this investigation, you will apply these conditions to a system that contains forces and torques to establish equilibrium.

Extension Activity 1 – 15 minutes

text: Establish the condition(s) necessary for a system to be in equilibrium.

pageData.text: It has long been predicted that robots will be able to aid humans and perform a wide range of tasks. Robots can enter areas that are hazardous for humans, such as nuclear power plants, or disaster zones. They can perform daily household chores like cleaning the floor. Robot-assisted minimally invasive surgeries have become routine in many medical facilities. There has also been an increased use of robots in the manufacturing industry. Despite these technological advancements, humanoid robots still have limitations.

Some of the technological advances that need to occur to bring the full potential and capabilities of humanoid robots include making them smarter and more agile. For this to occur, humanoid robots become more energy efficient with low energy consumption and less low-friction losses. Humanoid robotic applications will require high-speed, high-<button class='glossary-text'>torque</button> motors that are small and lightweight<sup>1</sup>. As researchers continue to solve these technological challenges, fully functional and autonomous humanoid robots become more of a reality.

1Kafader, U. (2023). Power density in robotics, a question of torque. Drive Tech.
https://drive.tech/en/stream-content/power-density-in-robotics-a-question-of-torque

2Robot in the library by Sheila Bennet of Libraries Taskforce is available under CC BY 2.0 at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/135302410@N02/26425560385

pageData.altText: A humanoid robot kneeling on one leg, addressing two individuals in the foreground.

pageData.subTitle: Torque
pageData.text: In linear motion, an unbalanced force causes changes in motion. In rotational motion, an unbalanced , τ, will cause changes in rotational motion. Torque is a vector quantity with SI units of N, m, and its direction is determined from the cross-product r × F and a related right-hand rule. The relationship for calculating torque is shown in Equation 1, where r is the or moment arm, the perpendicular distance from the line of action of the force to the axis of rotation (pivot or fulcrum), and F is the force.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: tau equals r cross product vector F equals r perpendicular times vector F

pageData.text: Figure 1 illustrates the perpendicular distance from the axis of rotation to the line of action of the force.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: diagram showing lever arm times force

pageData.text: As shown in Figure 1, the lever arm or moment arm can be calculated using trigonometry r⊥ = r sin ⁡θ, where θ is the angle between r and F. Substituting this relationship into the torque equation results in Equation 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: tau equals r F sine begin paren theta end paren

pageData.text: The torque vector is perpendicular to the plane defined by r and F; the torque vector is used to determine the direction the applied force will cause the object to rotate. If you point the thumb of your right hand in the direction of torque the curl of your fingers indicates the direction of rotation. Clockwise rotation is caused by negative torques; anticlockwise rotation is caused by positive torques. For example, to advance a screw inward you would apply a force to the handle that would cause the screwdriver to rotate clockwise; to advance a screw outward you would apply a force to the handle that would cause the screwdriver to rotate anticlockwise. The right-hand rule for torque is illustrated in Figure 2.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing the right-hand rule for torque

pageData.subTitle: Equilibrium
pageData.text: states if the forces acting on an object are in balance, meaning the net force is equal to zero, then the object’s linear motion will not change. For two dimensions, the conditions for linear motion to remain unchanged or to be in equilibrium are written:

pageData.altText: Equation 3: theta F sub horizontal equals theta F sub x equals 0
Equation 4: theta F sub vertical equals theta F sub v equals 0

pageData.text: According to <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s second law of motion</button>, force is equal to mass times acceleration, which means when an object is in equilibrium, the acceleration of the object is zero. When the acceleration is equal to zero, the object may be at rest or moving at constant velocity.

For an object’s rotational motion to remain unchanged, the acting on the object must be balanced. If it is rotating, it will keep rotating at a constant rate; if it is not rotating, it will continue to not rotate. The relationship which describes rotational equilibrium is shown in Equation 5.

pageData.altText: Equation 5: theta tau equals theta tau sub anticlockwise plus theta tau sub clockwise equals 0

pageData.text: Substitute the sign convention + and anticlockwise and − and clockwise, and the relationship can be rewritten as:
Στanticlockwise − Στclockwise = 0

pageData.altText: Equation 6: theta tau sub anti clockwise equals theta tau sub clockwise

pageData.text: The rotational counterpart to Newton’s second law of motion states torque, τ, is equal to , І, times , α. Moment of inertia is the rotational counterpart to mass, and angular acceleration is the rotational counterpart to linear acceleration.

pageData.altText: Equation 7: tau equals I alpha

pageData.text: Similar to linear motion, for a system to be in rotational equilibrium, angular acceleration, α, would equal zero. This condition may mean the system is not rotating or the system is rotating at a constant rate. The system you will be using in this experiment will not be rotating.

An example of a system in is shown in Figure 3. A beam with mass, m1, is pivoted at its center of mass, the support pivot also experiences the , N, equal to the weight of the beam. Mass, m2, is suspended at a distance of r1 to the left of the pivot, another mass, m3, is suspended at a distance of r2 to the right of the pivot putting the system onto equilibrium.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Free body diagram for static equilibrium

pageData.question: A seesaw with a mass, M, is perfectly balanced with a fulcrum at the center. Which of the following best describes the change in net torque if the mass uniformly increases to (3/2)M ? Assume the mass per unit length of the seesaw remains constant.

options.text: The net torque does not change because uniformly increasing the mass keeps the seesaw balanced and the net torque remains zero.
The net torque does not change because the increase in mass does not increase the torque.
The net torque increases because the increase in mass increases the net torque.
The net torque increases because the gravitational force increases with more mass, and torque is related to force.
The net torque decreases because the gravitational force increases with more mass, and torque is inversely related to force.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The seesaw is perfectly balanced initially and therefore has a net torque of zero.  The net torque does not change when the mass increases because uniformly increasing the mass keeps the seesaw balanced and the net torque remains zero.

pageData.question: Which of the following is the condition for rotational equilibrium?

options.text: All of these statements describe the condition of rotational equilibrium.
The sum of the counterclockwise torques is equal to the sum of the clockwise torques.
The sum of all torques on a system in rotational equilibrium is zero.
The net torque of the system is equal to zero.
None of these statements are true.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The condition for rotational equilibrium is described by all three statements.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An example of a system in static equilibrium is shown in Figure 3. A beam with mass, m1, is pivoted at its center of mass, the support pivot also experiences the normal force, N, equal to the weight of the beam. Mass, m2, is suspended at a distance of r1 to the left of the pivot, another mass, m3, is suspended at a distance of r2 to the right of the pivot putting the system onto equilibrium.

img.alt: Figure 3: Free body diagram for static equilibrium

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An example of a system in static equilibrium is shown in Figure 3. A beam with mass, m1, is pivoted at its center of mass, the support pivot also experiences the normal force, N, equal to the weight of the beam. Mass, m2, is suspended at a distance of r1 to the left of the pivot, another mass, m3, is suspended at a distance of r2 to the right of the pivot putting the system onto equilibrium.

img.alt: Figure 3: Free body diagram for static equilibrium

pageData.text: The weight of mass m2 provides a force which will tend to rotate the beam anticlockwise and the weight of mass m3 provides a force which will tend to rotate the beam clockwise. The weights of mass m2 and mass m3 both acts at 90-degree angles to the beam. A relationship between the masses can be determined using Equations 2 and 6.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: tau equals r F sine begin paren theta end paren
Equation 6: theta tau sub anti clockwise equals theta tau sub clockwise

pageData.text: Substitute the relationship of Equation 2 into Equation 6 for the anticlockwise and clockwise .
r 1m 2gsin90o = r 2m 3gsin90o
Substituting sin90o = 1 and dividing both sides by g, gives:

pageData.altText: Equation 8: r sub 1 m sub 2 equals r sub 2 m sub 3

pageData.text: The system in is also in translational equilibrium, the forces act in the vertical direction and will meet the condition of Equation 4.

pageData.altText: Equation 4: theta F sub vertical equals theta F sub v equals 0

pageData.text: Substituting in the forces (as shown in Figure 3) gives:
ΣFy = N - m 1g - m 2g - m 3g = 0

pageData.altText: Equation 9: N equals m sub 1 g plus m sub 2 g plus m sub 3 g

pageData.text: Note: the unknowns in Figure 3 can be determined using Equation 8 and Equation 9.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, measure the mass of the ruler, washers and string. Then, determine the center of mass of the ruler and assemble the apparatus.  In activity 1, add the large and small washers to the ends of the ruler, balance the ruler at its center of mass and move the large washer until the ruler is balanced. Next, record the location of the string at equilibrium, add another small washer and repeat until you have tested, 1, 2 and 3 small washers for 2 trials each.  Then, reset the apparatus, add 1 small washer and 2 large washers to the ends of the ruler and repeat the process of finding the equilibrium point for 1, 2 and 3 small washers for 2 trials each.  Next, draw a system diagram. Then, calculate the clockwise and anticlockwise torques and the percent difference for both systems. Finally, calculate the experimental mass of the ruler and percent error for the mass. Proceed to the extension activity.

A map of the procedural workflow of the extension activity of this investigation.  After completing Activity 1, in the extension activity, you will open the PHET activity “Balancing Act”. Then, you will place the mystery object and a known mass on the beam.  Next, you will move the objects to balance the beam. Then, you will calculate the mass of the mystery object. Finally, you will repeat this for all of the mystery objects in the simulation.

pageData.text: Wear your safety goggles at all times while conducting this investigation. Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation and clean up the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following equations represents the calculation of torque, τ ?
Which of the following is the SI unit for the unit torque, τ ?
A bridge is anchored and rests on two pillars.  Which of the following best describes the torque of the bridge?

options.text: The bridge has torques which are in equilibrium.
The bridge has no torque because it is not moving.
The bridge has no torque because there are only two pillars.
The bridge has torque because it is at rest.
There is not enough information to describe the torque.

assestmentData.question: A 15.0 g mass hangs from the 2.60 cm mark of a meter stick.   The meter stick has uniform mass per unit length and is pivoted at the center.  From what location on the meter stick should the 45.0 g mass be hung so the system is in equilibrium?
Which of the following best describes the center of mass?

options.text: The center of mass is the point in the object or system where all the mass can be considered located for the purpose of calculating the torques of said system.
The center of mass is the average of all the parts of mass that make up an object or system.
The center of mass is the geometric center of the object or system.
The center of mass is the quantitative measure of the translational and rotational inertia of the object or system.
The center of mass is the point of greatest mass of an object or system where the mass per unit length is not constant.

assestmentData.question: A 20.0 g mass hangs from the 12.5 cm mark of a meter stick.  The meter stick has uniform mass per unit length and pivoted at the center.  The meter stick is balanced when a mass, m, is hung from the 75.0 cm mark of the meter stick. What is the magnitude of the mass, m?

A 50.0 g mass hangs from the 41.5 cm mark of a uniform meter stick with a mass of 38.0 g. The meter stick is pivoted at the 60 cm mark.  From what location on the meter stick should a 65.0 g mass be hung so that the system is balanced?

A system consists of a mass of 25 g located at x = 1.0 cm, a mass of 35.0 g located at x = 5.0 cm, and a mass of 5.0 g located at x = 9.4 cm. Where along the x-axis is the center of mass of the system?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Create a work space.
Read through the procedure.
Gather the required materials.

Determine the mass of the ruler, the mass of each of the 3 small washers, and the mass of the 2 large washers. Record these values in Data Table 1 in the Lab Notebook. Try to locate small washers with the same mass; if your washers have different masses you will need to keep track of which ones you use for each trial so that when you repeat the measurements, you are using the same washers. The total mass of the 2 large washers should be > 49 g.
Fashion 2 mass hangers out of your paper clips.
Make 2 small loops with the string. You will be placing the loops of string around the ruler and attaching your paper clip mass hangers to them.
Determine the mass of each loop of string with its paper clip hanger and record these values in Data Table 1.

Determine the center of mass of the ruler. Find the location where the ruler will balance when you hold it up with your finger. Place the bottom, wide side of the ruler on your finger and adjust its location by moving the length of the ruler to the left or right as illustrated in Figure 4.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: illustrated hand with the index finger pointing to the center of a ruler and an arrow and red circle marking that point, which is the center mass

pageData.text: Another method of determining the center of mass of the ruler would be to tape a pencil to the side of a table and balance the ruler on the pencil or fashion a wedge out of a piece of cardboard to use as a pivot. The method used should support the ruler at its center of mass like a seesaw; choose the option that works the best for you. The objective is to determine the center of mass of the ruler, and this will not depend on the method used to balance the system. Record the location of the center of mass of your ruler in Data Table 2 and Data Table 4.

Place 1 loop of string with paper clip mass hanger (of known mass) at the zero location on the ruler. Affix this string with a small piece of transparent tape; this loop of string will remain at zero for all of your measurements.

In Activity 1, you will find the equilibrium length for two different masses of washers by balancing them on a ruler. You will then repeat the trials for 3 masses. You will use this data to calculate the experimental mass of the ruler and compare it to the actual mass.

typeBefore.text: Note: To simplify the calculations for this experiment, masses can be recorded in grams and distances recorded in centimeters. Record your values using the correct number of significant digits.

pageData.text: Place 1 small washer on the hanger at the zero position on the ruler. Place the other loop of string with paper clip hanger over the other end of the ruler; place the 1 large washer of known mass on the hanger.

Using your finger, a support object, or a pivot under the center of mass of the ruler, adjust the location of the string with the large washer to balance the system. Remember, the ruler can be supported by your finger, placed on a pencil taped to the table, or balanced on a pivot; choose the option that works the best for you; the method used should support the ruler at its center of mass. The objective is to establish equilibrium using the support, small washer, and large washer; this will not depend on the method used to balance the system.
Record the location of the string, with the suspended large washer, for equilibrium of the system in Data Table 2 (Trial 1; 1 small washer).
Place a second small washer on the hanger at the zero position on the ruler.

Place your finger under the location of the center of mass of the ruler, lift the ruler; adjust the location of the string with the 1 large washer to balance the system. Record the location of the string, with the suspended large washer, for equilibrium of the system in Data Table 2. (Trial 1; 2 small washers)
Place a third small washer on the hanger at the zero position on the ruler.

Place your finger under the location of the center of mass of the ruler. Lift the ruler; adjust the location of the string with the large washer to balance the system. Record the location of the string, with the suspended large washer, for equilibrium of the system in Data Table 2 (Trial 1; 3 small washers).

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a picture of your ruler and mass system in balance.
Remove the string with the large washer and remove the 3 small washers from the hanger at 0 cm. The loop of string and its mass hanger should remain affixed to the 0 cm location on the ruler.
Repeat Steps 1–6 for the second trials (Trial 2); record locations in Data Table 2.
Remove the string with the large washer and remove the 3 small washers from the hanger at 0 cm. The loop of string and its mass hanger should remain affixed to the 0 cm location on the ruler.
Place 1 small washer on the hanger at the zero position on the ruler. Place the other loop of string with paper clip hanger over the other end of the ruler; place the 2 large washers on the hanger.

Using your finger, support object, or a pivot under the 20.5 cm location on the ruler, adjust the location of the string with the 2 large washers to balance the system. Record the location of the string with the 2 large washers, which established equilibrium, in Data Table 4 (Trial 1; 1 small washer).
Place a second small washer on the hanger at the zero position on the ruler.

Place your finger under the 20.5 cm location on the ruler, lift the ruler, adjust the location of the string with the 2 large washers to balance the system. Record the location of the string with the 2 large washers, which established equilibrium, in Data Table 4 (Trial 1; 2 small washers).
Place a third small washer on the hanger at the zero position on the ruler.

Place your finger under the 20.5 cm location on the ruler, lift the ruler; adjust the location of the string with the 2 large washers to balance the system. Record the location of the string with the 2 large washers, which established equilibrium, in Data Table 4 (Trial 1; 3 small washers).
Remove the string with the large washer and remove the 3 small washers from the hanger at 0 cm. The loop of string and its mass hanger should remain affixed to the 0 cm location on the ruler.
Repeat Steps 2–7 for Trial 2; record locations in Data Table 4.
Draw a diagram of your ruler and mass system in equilibrium, identifying the anticlockwise <button class='glossary-text'>torque</button> and clockwise torque.
Calculate the anticlockwise torque and the clockwise torque of the system with the ruler and the washers. Record these values in Data Table 3. (Show a sample calculation.)
Calculate the percent difference in the torques and record the values in Data Table 3.
Did your experiment results in Data Table 3 verify, to within a reasonable experimental error, the condition of equilibrium of Equation 6? Support your response with experimental data.

pageData.altText: Equation 6: theta tau sub anti clockwise equals theta tau sub clockwise

pageData.text: Draw a diagram of your ruler and mass system in equilibrium, identifying the anticlockwise torque(s) and clockwise torque(s).
Calculate the anticlockwise torque and the clockwise torque of the system with the ruler and the washers. Record these values in Data Table 5. (Show a sample calculation.)
Calculate the percent difference in the torques and record the values in Data Table 5.
Did your experiment results in Data Table 5 verify, to within a reasonable experimental error, the condition of equilibrium of Equation 6? Support your response with experimental data.

pageData.altText: Equation 6: theta tau sub anti clockwise equals theta tau sub clockwise

pageData.text: Use the data in Data Tables 4 and 5 to experimentally determine the mass of your ruler. Use one of your two trials with 1 small washer at 0 cm, one of your two trials with 2 small washers at 0 cm, and one of your two trials with 3 small washers at 0 cm to find three experimental values for the mass of the ruler.

Compare the 3 experimental masses of your ruler to the measured mass of your ruler (Data Table 1) by calculating the percent error for each experimental value. Which trial provided the best data for determining the mass of the ruler?

pageData.title: PhET Balancing Act Lab Activity
pageData.text: In the Extension Activity, you will use a simulation to determine the mass of mystery objects by balancing them on a beam, finding the equilibrium length, and calculating the clockwise and anticlockwise .

text: Determine the mass of mystery objects using the conditions of <button class='glossary-text'>static equilibrium</button>.

A window washer stands on a uniform plank of mass M = 142 kg and length l = 2.80 m supported by 2 ropes attached at the ends of the plank. The window washer has a mass m = 68.0 kg. What is the tension in each of the ropes, T1 and T2, if the window washer’s displacement from the center of mass of the plank is x = 0.930 as shown in the figure below.

pageData.altText: A man on a plank suspended by its ends from two ropes T1 and T2. The mass of the man has a downward force lowercase m times g. The mass of the plank has a downward force capital M times g. The man is displaced from the center of the plank by distance x.

header.text: Object
Mass (kg)
Calculation

tableData.text:
Anticlockwise Torque = Clockwise Torque
FA x 1.5 m = 15 kg (g) x 2.0 m
mA (g) = [(15 kg (g)) x 20 m] /1.5 m
mA = 20 kg

pageData.content: Investigation Overview
Equation 1. Torque (when θ = 90)
pageData.altText: Equation 1: tau equals r cross product vector F equals r perpendicular times vector F

pageData.content: Figure 1. The perpendicular distance from the axis of rotation to the line of action of force
pageData.altText: Figure 1: diagram showing lever arm times force

pageData.content: Equation 2.  Torque
pageData.altText: Equation 2: tau equals r F sine begin paren theta end paren

pageData.content: Figure 2. The right-hand rule for torque
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing the right-hand rule for torque

pageData.content: Equation 3. Sum of horizontal forces in equilibrium
pageData.altText: Equation 3: theta F sub horizontal equals theta F sub x equals 0

pageData.content: Equation 4. Sum of vertical forces in equilibrium
pageData.altText: Equation 4: theta F sub vertical equals theta F sub v equals 0

pageData.content: Equation 5. Sum of torque in equilibrium
pageData.altText: Equation 5: theta tau equals theta tau sub anticlockwise plus theta tau sub clockwise equals 0

pageData.content: Equation 6. Torque in Equilibrium
pageData.altText: Equation 6: theta tau sub anti clockwise equals theta tau sub clockwise

pageData.content: Equation 7.  Torque in terms of moment of inertia and angular acceleration
pageData.altText: Equation 7: tau equals I alpha

pageData.content: Figure 3. System in static equilibrium
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Free body diagram for static equilibrium

pageData.content: Equation 8.  System in static equilibrium for Figure 3
pageData.altText: Equation 8: r sub 1 m sub 2 equals r sub 2 m sub 3

pageData.content: Equation 9. Sum of vertical forces for Figure 3
pageData.altText: Equation 9: N equals m sub 1 g plus m sub 2 g plus m sub 3 g

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram
pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, measure the mass of the ruler, washers and string. Then, determine the center of mass of the ruler and assemble the apparatus.  In activity 1, add the large and small washers to the ends of the ruler, balance the ruler at its center of mass and move the large washer until the ruler is balanced. Next, record the location of the string at equilibrium, add another small washer and repeat until you have tested, 1, 2 and 3 small washers for 2 trials each.  Then, reset the apparatus, add 1 small washer and 2 large washers to the ends of the ruler and repeat the process of finding the equilibrium point for 1, 2 and 3 small washers for 2 trials each.  Next, draw a system diagram. Then, calculate the clockwise and anticlockwise torques and the percent difference for both systems. Finally, calculate the experimental mass of the ruler and percent error for the mass. Proceed to the extension activity.

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram (cont... )
pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of the extension activity of this investigation.  After completing Activity 1, in the extension activity, you will open the PHET activity “Balancing Act”. Then, you will place the mystery object and a known mass on the beam.  Next, you will move the objects to balance the beam. Then, you will calculate the mass of the mystery object. Finally, you will repeat this for all of the mystery objects in the simulation.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: illustrated hand with the index finger pointing to the center of a ruler and an arrow and red circle marking that point, which is the center mass

data.title: Angular acceleration (a)
data.content: The rate of change in angular velocity with respect to time

data.title: Lever arm
data.content: The perpendicular distance from the fulcrum of a lever to the line of action of the effor or the line of action of the weight

data.title: Moment of inertia
data.content: A quantity expressing a body's tendency to resist angular acceleration

data.title: Newton's first law of motion
data.content: The law of inertia; states an object at rest remains at rest and an object in motion remains in motion at constant speed unless acted upon by unbalanced forces

data.title: Newton's second law of motion
data.content: States the net force is equal to mass times acceleration

data.title: Normal force (N)
data.content: That component of the contact force between two objects, which acts perpendicularly to and away from their plane of contact

data.title: Static equilibrium
data.content: A physical state in which an object is at rest with no net force and no net torque acting on it

data.title: Torque (τ)
data.content: A vector quantity; a measure of the force that can cause an object to rotate about an axis
